--- John Arrowwood <jarrowwx@...> wrote:
> This gives me an interesting idea...
> 
> Imagine a program that takes in a network
> definition, analyzes it, and 
> produces optimized C code for processing it. 
> Suppose you had a domain (like 
> the one I'm looking at) where network activation is
> very much the bulk of 
> the time.  Something like that would allow the
> experiment to run much 
> faster.
> 
> Of course, a more realistic approach is to store
> information about how to 
> rapidly calculate a network result along with the
> network.  Then, you can 
> activate the network as many times as you need to,
> optimally.  You simply 
> have an initial overhead cost of the analysis and
> 'strategy' determination.
> 
> No, such a thing is definitely overkill for xor. 
> But for image enlargement, 
> where analyzing the fitness of a single network may
> involve billions (yes, 
> billions) of activations, every little bit will
> help.
<snip>

The ANN code in my programs is extremely fast in
execution, but does not cover a general topology.  I
have two varieties.  One is the standard MLP, with
roughly sigmoidal neurons.  The other is the fully
connected recurrent binary net, similar to a Hopfield
network.  If either of those suit your application,
then you can use my code.

=====
Mitchell Timin
